name: leprechaun
sources: Evans-Wentz, W. Y. The Fairy-Faith in Celtic Countries. Gerrards Cross: Colin Smythe Humanities Press, 1911, 241-242.
Keightley, Thomas. The Fairy Mythology. London: H. G. Bohn, 1870.
Kennedy, Patrick. Legendary Fictions of the Irish Celts. (New York: Benjamin Blom, 1969), 130.
Wilde, Lady. Ancient Legends, Mystic Charms and Superstitions of Ireland. London: Chatto and Windus, 1902, 56+.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Irish folklore includes the leprechaun (known as leipreachán, lùracán, luchramán, luchragán, luchorpán, lupracánaig, lurikeen), a dwarfish man with green clothing who is known for being able to locate the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. This Irish Fairy is just one of a variety of Irish fairy species; the leprechaun differs from other more common fairies, like the Trooping Fairies who would often lead travelers astray with their singing and dancing. Unlike these fairies, the leprechaun was solitary (sometimes referred to as a Solitary Fairy) and was rarely encountered. If found, the leprechaun could only give up the location of its treasure if captured and held while still clearly in sight. The fairy's preferred method of escape was to claim that a monster was approaching, leading the captor to look away, at which point the leprechaun would disappear. The word leprechaun itself comes from leith brogan meaning “maker of the shoe” and refers to the fairy's occupation as a shoemaker, though they were also known to be tailors. While similar to the Scottish and British Brownie, the leprechaun differed as it was often self-employed. The little man had a surly character and could become malice if crossed; hence, it was essential to deal politely with the fairy. Some evidence suggests that this fairy tale figure may have come from the legendary god Lugh, sometimes known as Lugh-chromain, “little stooped Lugh,” who was the patron of arts and treasure. After Christianization, Lugh faded from prominence but remained in this folklore figure. A race of small-bodied monsters, said to have been begotten by the biblical Noah’s son Ham due to his father's curse, is mentioned in The Book Of Invasions. These monsters might have served as a mythical model for the leprechaun. Literary works also feature the leprechaun, most notably James Stevens' Crock of Gold, a comic novel from the early 20th century, which formed the foundation for the widely-known American musical (and later film) Finian's Rainbow.
